the  most

Benefits Evaluation. The Project will lay down an analytical framework 
and  a  data  collection  mechanism  for  the  impact  evaluation  of  its 
commune council facilities component, to be done at a later date. The 
evaluation  method  will  combine  the  methods  of  propensity  score 
matching and double differences, using commune and household data. 
The  data  will  be  collected  through  three-stage  surveys  (province, 
commune, and household), with sample households from each sampled 
commune  stratified  by  poverty  level  (poorest,  middle  income,  and 
richest). The total sample will comprise 100 project communes and 100 
nonproject  communes,  with  15  households  to  be  surveyed  in  each 
sampled commune. The baseline survey will be done at the start of the 
Project.  A  similar  survey  will  be  done  at  project  completion.  ADB  will 
work with DoLA to develop a specific design for the surveys. This data 
collection mechanism will be funded under the Project. 
 
Corruption  is  a  project  risk.  Construction  funds  could  be  misused, 
materials  used  could  be  defective  or  of  poor  quality,  or  inferior  design 
standards  could  be  applied.  This  risk  will  be  mitigated  by  (i)  project 
design, which sets rigorous quality specification and control standards, 
including  an  operations  manual  for  constructors;  (ii)  quality  checks 
before,  during,  and  after  construction  by  a  permanent  project  team 
formed for this purpose; (iii) standardized designs, which facilitate cost 
monitoring  and  control;  (iv)  very  tight  cost  margins,  which  minimize 
opportunities  to  overstate  costs;  and  (v)  moral  suasion  resulting  from 
the  high  status  accorded  to  the  construction  of  commune  council 
buildings under the Project. 
 
There  is  also  the  risk  that  the  local  administration  will  still  have  weak 
capacity by the time the responsibilities and resources are turned over, 
or that the commune councils will not be sufficiently responsive to their 
constituents’  needs.  The  capacity  development  component  of  this 
project,  in  conjunction  with  diverse  activities  of  other  development 
partners, is aimed at mitigating capacity gaps. This risk will be mitigated 
by  (i)  the  public  awareness  campaign  funded  by  the  Project,  (ii)  the 
actions of other donors, and (iii) the competitive political process at the 
local  level,  which  is  expected  to  make  local  officials  more  sensitive  to 
the needs of their communities because of electoral accountability.   
 
There  is  moreover  a  risk  that  the  process  of  decentralization  and 
deconcentration  will  be  mismanaged,  incompletely  implemented,  or 
substantially  delayed.  There  is  the  risk  as  well  that  after  the  functions 
are  transferred,  not  enough  resources  will  be  provided  and  local 
governments will therefore remain weak. This uncertainty goes beyond 
the scope of this project, but it is partly mitigated by the Government’s 
commitment  to  its  reform  agenda,  as  evidenced  most  recently  by  the 
preparation  of  a  draft  Organic  Law 
for  Deconcentration  and 
Decentralization  and  the  preparation  of  an  implementation  framework 
for  this  purpose.  It  is  further  mitigated  by  the  participation  of  other 
development  partners  working  with  the  Government  to  address  key 
implementation issues.

Rationale and Analysis 

 
A.  
 
Public administration reform and local governance are key areas of Asian Development 
2. 
Bank (ADB) support under the current country strategy and program (CSP) for the Kingdom of 
Cambodia  2005–2009. 1  This  Project  is  a  follow-up  to  the  Commune  Council  Development 
Project (CCDP), which was approved by ADB in 2002 to assist the Government in ensuring that 
in  the  medium  term  all  commune  councils  would  have  the  facilities  and  basic  equipment  to 
function  effectively.2 The  CCDP  has  been  successfully  implemented.3 Commune  councils  are 
recognized  as  playing  an  essential  role  in  the  promotion  of  democratic  practices  and  in  the 
socioeconomic development of rural Cambodia. However, as in 2002, many communes do not 
have  office  facilities  or  operate  in  temporary  and  dilapidated  wood  structures,  and  thus  have 
seriously impaired capacity to positively influence the welfare of local communities.  
 
Commune  Councils. Cambodia is an overwhelmingly rural country. More than 80% of 
3. 
the population lives in rural areas and poverty incidence ranges from 40% to 60%  (Cambodia 
CSP 2005–2009). Cambodia has 1,621 communes and sangkats. Of this total, 1,510 are mostly 
rural  communes  in  the  20  provinces,  and  111  are  urban  sangkats  in  the  four  municipalities 
(mostly  in  Phnom  Penh).  Commune  councils  are  the  lowest  level  of  public  administration  in 
Cambodia.  The  Commune  Administration  Act  2001  gave  councils  “local  affairs”  duties  to 
maintain  security  and  public  order;  manage  public  services;  promote  welfare,  economic,  and 
social development; protect and conserve the environment; and promote tolerance and mutual 
understanding. The 2002 subdecree decentralizing powers, roles, and duties set out two broad 
roles  for  commune  councils:  promoting  development  and  achieving  greater  democracy. 
However,  these  powers  are  discretionary  and  supplementary:  councils  are  not  responsible  for 
police, education, health, and other major services.

commune. In the first commune and sangkat elections (February 2002) 11,261 commune and 
sangkat councilors were elected (8.5% were female and 10.2% were from ethnic minorities) for 
a  term  of  5  years.  The  second  commune  and  sangkat  elections  will  be  in  April 2007.  The 
councilors  receive  a  small  monthly  stipend.  Only  one  staff  member  of  the  council,  the  council 
clerk, is a Ministry of Interior (MoI) employee. The councils’ main revenue source is a formula-

mainly used in small-scale rural infrastructure, and the rest goes to the council’s administrative 
costs.  The  small  average  size  of  communes  and  sangkats  is  a  major  constraint  on  their 
potential  capacity  as  direct  service  providers.  Being  small,  however,  also  means  that  councils 
are  close  to  the  people.  Councilors  can  therefore  play  a  key  role  in  services  such  as  the 
resolution of family and other disputes, and the maintenance of local peace and order. Councils 
also support the implementation of the Land Law 2001: they conduct land use planning, resolve 
local  plot  disputes,  and  monitor  illegal  use.  They  have  been  given  direct  responsibility  for  two 
important state infrastructure services: civil registration (CR) (of births, deaths, and marriages) 
and maintenance of the electoral database. All councils are also involved in planning, allocating, 
and  implementing  local  infrastructure  and  other  rural  development  investments  financed  from 
the Commune and Sangkat Fund. 
 
5. 
The  most  comprehensive  independent  study  of  commune  and  sangkat  council 
performance  to  date,  commissioned  by  the  Asia  Foundation,4 found  that  citizens  are  generally 
satisfied with the performance of their councils, and that the resolution of commune issues has 
improved  since  the  introduction  of  elected  councils.  Citizens  are  aware  of  commune  council 
functions.  Local  development  projects  appear  to  be  free  from  elite  capture  and  are  seen  to 
benefit  the  majority  rather  than  the  few.  The  study  found  that  dispute  mediation  is  the  main 
councilor  activity,  other  than  administrative  tasks,  and  that  commune  councilors  are  now  as 
likely to be involved in dispute resolution as village chiefs. Councilors are reportedly approached 
by local residents (5 to 10 each day) for help in resolving local disputes, mostly about land or 
irrigation, and family disagreements. Overall, the study findings were positive about the growing 
role, mandate, and competence of the commune councils. 
 
6. 
Rationale  for  Supporting  Commune  Councils.  Supporting  commune  councils  is  a 
priority because, first, they are directly entrusted with basic state infrastructure (CR) and support 
for land registration, processes that are vital in giving people greater access to essential justice 
administration,  such  as  the  protection  of  property  rights,  and  other  fundamental  services 
provided by the state. Councilors’ effectiveness in resolving disputes, supporting essential land 
titling and management processes, and planning and implementing small-scale infrastructure is 
essential in sustaining increases in agricultural productivity, the determinant of living standards 
in rural Cambodia. The role of the councils in spreading the benefits of civil and land registration 
(and  other  state-building  processes)  is  crucial  in  increasing  the  outreach  and  effectiveness  of 
public  services  to  the  rural  population  (targeting  of  education  and  health-care  efforts,  and  of 
agriculture policy instruments). Commune councils, by serving as a stable institutional platform 
closer to the people, also greatly enhance the above-mentioned outreach and effectiveness of 
public  services  provided  by  other  tiers  of  subnational  administration  to  the  communes.  Most

7. 
Although  commune  councils  will  have  limited  direct  control  over  service  delivery,  in  a 
country  with  little  history  of  local  participation  and  empowerment,  it  is  crucial  to  develop  the 
representative “voice of the people” on the quality of local services provided by higher levels of 
subnational  public  administration.  Besides  providing  direct  feedback  on  public  services, 
commune councils can be more fundamentally empowered as a result of the ongoing plans for 
decentralization and deconcentration (D&D). The relevance of supporting commune councils for 
this reason is implicitly recognized in the current CSP for Cambodia with a firm commitment to 
assist the Government in ensuring that in the medium term all commune councils will have the 
basic  conditions  to  function  effectively.  However,  ADB  and  the  Government  have  also 
recognized  that  the  effect  on  local  economic  development  from  supporting  commune  councils 
depends  heavily  on  the  pace  of  overall  D&D.  In  other  words,  the  effectiveness  of  the  direct 
functions of the commune councils and of their scrutiny of subnational public services depends 
on whether public service functions are indeed being decentralized and deconcentrated to the 
provinces and districts. 
 
8. 
Decentralization  and  Deconcentration. In June 2005, to establish the objectives and 
principles  for  all  the  required  changes  in  public  management  structures  in  Cambodia,  the 
Government  approved  the  Strategic  Framework  for  Decentralization  and  Deconcentration 
(SFDD).  The  SFDD  is  intended  to  frame  all  policies,  legal  instruments,  and  operational 
procedures  of  ministries  and  institutions  of  the  Government  regarding  the  management  and 
distribution of responsibilities and resources to the provincial, municipal, district and khan, and 
commune  and  sangkat  levels.  Organic  laws  that  are  now  being  prepared  will  constitute  the 
basic legal framework for implementing these major changes in public administration. A draft of 
the  new  Organic  Law  under  preparation  since April  2006  is  now  being  translated and  is to  be 
submitted to the National Assembly in early 2007. The proposals in the draft Organic Law are 
expected  to  be  submitted  to  the  National  Assembly  by  early  2007,  to  create  unified 
administrations  and  indirectly  elected  councils  (elected  by  the  commune  and  sangkat 
councilors) in provinces, districts, municipalities, and khans (urban districts). This is a major step 
forward  in  increasing  the  potential  for  voice  and  participation,  and  in  structurally  improving 
subnational governance.  
 
9. 
In  essence,  with  the  future  implementation  of  the  Organic  Law,  authority  for  providing 
some  public  services  will  be  delegated  to  the  provincial  and  district  administrations,  enabling 
these  to  effectively  avoid  the  current  overlapping  and  duplication  of  those  functions  with  line 
ministries;  and  democratic  mechanisms  of  scrutiny  and  accountability  of  government  will  be 
established as these unified administrations will be accountable to the newly created respective 
councils.  As  local  administration  in  Cambodia  undergoes  significant  changes,  the  commune 
councils  will  be  awarded  with  an  increasingly  important  role  in  subnational  affairs.  However, 
deep deficiencies in institutional, physical, and human capacity persist, threatening to jeopardize 
the potential effectiveness of the reforms.

Component 2: Civil Registration System Development. The output of component 2 is 
a  sustainable  computer-based  CR  system  with  secured  hard-copy  records  and  a  central

implementing  component  2  will  be  to:  secure  storage  facilities  for  one  copy  of  all  CR  record 
books  within  the  MoI  in  Phnom  Penh;  arrange  for  one  copy  of  all  complete  CR  books  to  be 
transferred to MoI, and filed and indexed accurately; recruit (by the Government) additional staff

A  system  for  collecting,  updating,  and  analyzing  CR  records  of  births,  deaths,  and 
marriages  is  an  essential  element  of  any  country’s  demographic  infrastructure.  Because  they 
establish  documentary  evidence  of  parentage,  marriage,  age,  origin,  and  family  structure,  CR 
records  are  also  the  essential  foundation  for  human,  gender,  and  child  rights,  as  these  will 
ensure  the  conservation  of  vital  records  and  thus  promote  legal  certainty,  transparency, 
protection  of  women’s  and  children’s  property  and  inheritance  rights  from  abuse,  and 
predictability  in  accessing  basic  social  services  and  productive  resources.  The  MoI  has 
expressed  its  long-standing  concern  to  preserve  the  hard-copy  CR  records,  which  are  now 
stored in 180 district offices and provincial courts, many of them threatened by humidity, floods, 
and  deterioration,  and  to  establish  a  modern  computerized  system  for  cataloging,  accessing, 
and updating the records. This component effectively tackles the most urgent task of halting the 
deterioration of the collected records.

1. 
Overview.  Cambodia  is  traditionally  a  centralized  society.  The  long-term  institutional 
reform  process  of  decentralization  and  deconcentration  (D&D)  of  public  decision  making  and 
services delivery was started in 2001 with the creation of the commune councils, and with the 
direct  elections  for  these  councils  in  February  2002.  This  process  has  been  the  single  most 
significant  state-building  development  since  the  1993  Constitution.  It  is  implicitly  aimed  at 
strengthening three key conditions of state effectiveness: organizational design, structure of the 
political system, and legitimization. Draft legislation (Organic—or constitutional—Law) to reform 
the  entire  subnational  state  structure  (provinces,  districts,  and  communes  in  rural  areas  and 
municipalities;  khans  and  sangkats  in  urban  areas)  is  now  being  reviewed  within  government 
and  is  expected  to  be  submitted  to  the  National  Assembly  in  2007.  This  draft  legislation 
anticipates  the  formation  of  new  councils,  elected  by  commune  councilors,  in  provinces  and 
districts, and the progressive devolution of responsibility for delivering major services from line 
ministries to “unified administrations” in provinces and districts. Important new opportunities thus 
open up for increased accountability through greater democratic scrutiny of service provision.1 
 
2. 
Subnational  Structure.  After  the  Paris  peace  talks  in  1991,  Cambodia’s  new  1993 
Constitution  created  a  national  structure  of  administration  comprising  20  provinces  with  171 
districts, and four municipalities (Phnom Penh, Kep, Pailin, and Sihanoukville) with 14 khans. At 
the  lowest  tier  of  state  administration  are  the  commune  and  sangkat.  Cambodia  has  1,621 
communes and sangkats. Of these, 1,510 are (mostly rural) communes in the 20 provinces, and 
111  are  urban  sangkats  in  the  municipalities,  most  of  them  in  Phnom  Penh.2 Until  2002,  all 
these subnational entities were run by appointed governors, accountable upward to the Ministry 
of  Interior  (MoI).  Public  services  are  delivered  by  vertically  accountable  line  ministries,  with 
minimal operational linkage with the provincial, district, or commune authorities.

1. 
In  Cambodia,  the  adoption  of  the  Law  on  Commune/Sangkat  Administration  and 
Management and the election of commune councils (2002) marked a first significant step in the 
implementation  of  decentralization.  Women  represented  only  16%  of  candidates.  A  total  of 
11,257  commune  councilors  were  elected  in  1,621  communes,  but,  of  these,  only  951  (8%) 
were women. Only about one third of commune councils have a woman councilor.1 This was a 
source of concern for the Ministry of Women’s Affairs (MoWA), and in 2003 it was decided that 
each commune council should have a women and children focal point (WCFP) to be in charge 
of  women’s  and  children’s  affairs. 2 The  need  to  support  women  councilors  and  WCFPs  in 
becoming  effective  partners  of  commune  councils  was  identified  by  the  MoWA  in  its  Gender 
Mainstreaming Evaluation Report (2005). In 2006, the Set Koma (Children’s Rights) Project of 
the  United  Nations  Children’s  Fund  (UNICEF)  was  approved.  Its  intent  was  to  strengthen  the 
capacity  of  provincial  and  district  women’s  affairs’  officials  to  train  WCFPs  and  women 
councilors in organizing and facilitating forums for elected women councilors and WCFPs, and 
establishing gender networks at the district and commune level. The forums were envisaged to 
provide  a  viable  setting  for  interaction  and  lateral  learning  between  and  among  WCFPs  and 
female  commune  councilors  on  critical  needs  and  constraints  faced  in  the  fulfillment  of  their 
roles  and  responsibilities,  and  the  identification  of  practical  modalities  to  address  identified 
needs  and  constraints.  In  Cambodia,  while  the  Government  has  been  largely  successful  in 
fostering  commitment  and  action  toward  promoting  gender  equality,  some  areas  still  require 
attention. These include the chronic under-participation of women in the commune councils and 
the lack of empowerment and self-esteem of women councilors and WCFPs.

Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in Cambodia: 
Cambodia  is  historically  a  centralized,  hierarchical,  elite-driven  society.  It  is  widely  believed  that  increased  popular 
voice, accountability, and participation are important drivers of increased equity in the use of national resources, and 
poverty reduction. The 2001 decision to create elected commune government for the first time in the nation’s history 
has created significant opportunities to strengthen participation and popular voice over time. The Strategic Framework 
for Decentralization and Deconcentration Reforms (June 2005), the subsequent discussion at the Eighth Consultative 
Group meeting of the Government and donors in March 2006, and the publication of the implementation framework for 
the first preparatory phase for subnational democratic development in June 2006 indicate a deepening commitment to 
more influential and participatory local government. By supporting local public administration reforms in an integrated 
way with the ongoing long-term institutional process of decentralization and deconcentration of public administration, 
the Project will make a direct contribution to meeting the difficult challenge of refocusing many aspects of government 
and  public  services  delivery,  and  giving  an  increasingly  larger  role  to  commune  councils  in  Cambodia.  Local  public 
administration  has  been  recognized  to  play  an  essential  role  in  the  promotion  of  democratic  practices  and  in  the 
country’s  socioeconomic  development.  It  can  potentially  increase  local  voice  and  representation  in  issues  such  as 
land-use rights, common property and natural resources use, and scrutiny of public service delivery by higher levels of 
subnational public administration. All this contributes to the efficiency of private capital accumulation and reduction of 
vulnerabilities in local economic activity. 
 
In  the  Commune  Council  Development  Project  (CCDP),  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB),  together  with  the 
Swedish International Development Cooperation Agency and the Government of the Netherlands, has developed an 
important  niche  of  support  for  the  decentralization  process.  Many  other  donors  have  sought  to  use  communes  as  a 
means  of  delivering  rural  development  interventions  through  the  Seila  Program,  the  Commune  Fund,  and  other 
bilateral  and  NGO  projects.  CCDP  has  focused  directly  on  the  core  capacities  and  functions  of  commune  councils, 
aside from their role as implementers of their commune development funds. The assessment of the CCDP review in 
March  2006  is  that  such  a  focused  approach  has  been  both  successful  and  appreciated  by  a  wide  spectrum  of 
stakeholders  from  the  central  Government  to  the  general  public.  The  effects  of  having  distinctive  and  appropriate 
council premises, better council communications, training and public awareness raising, commune photomapping, and 
a nascent national civil registration (CR) system are increasingly clear in terms of consolidating the local democratic 
process and essential local state building. Commune democracy  has been one of the  most important developments 
since 1993 in deepening the democratization process in Cambodia. Building on the achievements of CCDP, the three 
components  of  this  Project—enabling  more  commune  councils  to  operate  effectively,  developing  the  national  CR 
system,  strengthening  popular  understanding  of  democratic  rights  and  accountabilities—are  designed  as  a  further 
contribution to strengthening the institutions of open, participatory democracy at subnational levels, on which poverty 
reduction, human, and gender rights depend.

Is there a participation strategy? 
 
The project purpose (outcome and impact) is to increase democratic participation by consolidating and embedding the 
local  democracy  reforms  launched  by  the  Government  in  2001.  The  impact  on  national  participation  systems  will 
increase over time, following the Government’s plans to increase the remit of elected commune councilors to serve as 
members of district, municipal, and provincial councils. 
 
The quality of participation in a democracy depends in part on the quality of the electoral system. There is evidence 
that participation has been improving steadily over time. In the 1993 national elections, 4.8 million people voted. This 
number  increased  to  5.4  million  in  1998  and  6.3  million  in  2003.  In  the  2002  commune  elections,  5.2  million  people 
voted. Following the national elections in 2003, the National Election Commission (NEC) introduced a new registration 
system, based on a permanent voter list, updated by commune councils every year. By December 2005, the number 
of registered voters had reached 6.7 million. Together with other procedural changes in the NEC, and in the electoral 
process, the evidence is that the quality of democracy—and thus of national participation—is steadily improving. 
 
D.  Gender Development 
 
Strategy to maximize benefits for women: 
 
The democratic elections for the 1,621 commune councils that were held for the first time in 2002 (and that will be held 
again in 2007) provided an unprecedented opportunity for women in Cambodia (51%–52% of the population) to have 
an  equal  voice  in  appointing  their  representatives  (the  councilors).  In  terms  of  direct  political  participation,  and  as  a 
consequence  of  the  political  competition  process  between  parties,  16%  of  the  candidates  for  that  election  were 
women. However, of the total of 11,257 commune councilors that were elected in the 1,621 communes, only 951 (8%) 
were  women.  This  suggests  that  the  distribution  of  skills  within  communes  is  biased  against  women.  Before  the 
commune  election  in  February  2002,  the  Ministry  of  Women’s  Affairs  (MoWA)  and  several  nongovernment 
organizations (NGOs) advocated a 30% quota for women. Party leaders publicly agreed that women deserve greater 
political participation but rejected a quota system. Only about one third of commune councils have a woman councilor. 
In 2003, at the suggestion of MoWA, it was decided that each commune council should have a women and children 
focal point (WCFP). This was seen as necessary, given that the majority of commune councils had no female elected 
representatives. Now by law (Art. 19 of Sub-decree 22) every council must appoint a woman councilor to be in charge 
of  women’s  and  children’s  affairs.  If  a  council  does  not  have  a  female  elected  member,  it  should  appoint  a  woman 
from  the  commune  for  this  task.  While  the  Government  was  largely  successful  in  fostering  commitment  and  action 
toward promoting equality, some areas continue to require attention. These include the chronic under-participation of 
women  within  commune  councils’  affairs  and  the  lack  of  empowerment  and  self-esteem  of  women  councilors.  The 
2007 elections  will provide an important opportunity to  promote more  women  as commune councilors and to further 
advance gender equity within the resulting public administration processes and structures. In this context, the need for 
continuous support for empowering newly elected women councilors and WCFPs in effectively performing their roles 
and  responsibilities  is  critical  and  forms  the  rationale  for  the  proposed  gender  design  features  within  the  Commune 
Council Development Project 2 (CCDP2). 
 
Has an output been prepared?
